content.question:
<math alttext="The figure presents a four row table, with two columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “x.” The heading for row 2 is “f of x.” The heading for row 3 is “g of x.” The heading for row 4 is “g prime of x.” The data in the table are as follows Column 1. x is 0. f of x is 2. g of x is 0. g prime of x is 3. Column 2. x is 2. f of x is negative 1. g of x is 1. g prime of x is negative 2." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0.0em" columnwidth="3em 0.05em 3em 3em " frame="solid" framespacing="0.0em 0ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="0.05ex" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>x</mi></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd></mtd><mtd></mtd><mtd></mtd><mtd></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>
Let <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function given by <math alttext="f of x, equals, the integral from, negative 3 to x, of, g of t, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is a differentiable function. The table above gives selected values for <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="g prime" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math>. If <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the function given by <math alttext="h of x, equals, x squared, minus e to the x power, plus 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, for which of the following values of <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="h of x, equals, f prime of 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

topic.text: 6.4: The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus and Accumulation Functions

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
